Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative HSI Conference: Co-designing an engineering education research agenda

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Science Foundation Dear Colleague letter NSF 17-092: Improving Undergraduate STEM Education in Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs) calls for conference proposals that will help identify challenges and opportunities in STEM education at Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSIs). Given the lack of resources that many engineering educators face attending conferences, this proposal consists of a series of traveling workshops that target engineering educators from HSIs. The focus on these workshops is to leverage design thinking methodologies to better understand the HSI institutional context and co-develop research need with educators through an iterative and emergent analysis process.

The two-day workshops will take place at the University of Texas at El Paso (PI institution) and the University of Miami (Coral Gables, FL). Texas and Florida have some of the highest concentration of HSIs in the country, and both locations are within a short driving distance to several 2-year and 4-year institutions considered HSIs. Pre-workshop activities will help participants establish a baseline understanding of the needs, values, cultures, and characteristics of participants and their home institutions. During the workshop, participants will be introduced to three educational approaches that will help them examine their own beliefs and contexts and develop initial questions of interest about their institution, their students, and themselves as it relates to positively impacting the educational experiences of their students. The three approaches are Design Thinking, Intrinsic Motivation, and students as Empowered Agents. Using these ideas, participants will also develop a prototype of something they can try upon returning to their institution, and, through this prototyping process, they will continue to record emerging research questions and needs. A follow-up workshop at the ASEE Conference in June of 2018 will allow participants to share their reactions to their prototype experience. This workshop will also serve to disseminate and refine the resulting research agenda. The expected outcomes of this proposal are to produce (1) a set of research questions and needs to support the National Science Foundation's development of an HSI-focused research agenda, (2) educational experiments and prototypes for dissemination within the conference community and (3) a conference-design framework for identifying non-obvious research needs and engaging educators in the engineering education research and scholarship process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary:

In response to the NSF Dear Colleague Letter: Improving Undergraduate STEM Education in Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs), this collaborative project sought to uncover the non-obvious needs and existing successes at HSIs that can be addressed and amplified in future NSF initiatives to improve undergraduate engineering education.

 

After decades of focus on increasing diversity in engineering, Latinx students continue to be underrepresented in undergraduate engineering education programs. In 2014 the percentage of engineering bachelor degrees awarded to Hispanic students was 10.1% (Yoder, 2015). Of Hispanic students pursuing engineering degrees, at least 59% obtain their degrees from HSIs (Santiago & Soliz, 2012). To increase the representation of Hispanic individuals in the engineering field, our team focused on identifying and amplifying the successful efforts already in place at HSIs and developing approaches to address areas still needing refinement in existing HSI engineering education programs.

In particular, we designed and executed a multi-site, multi-day workshop series, Rethinking Engineering Education at Hispanic Serving Institutions (http://eel.utep.edu/hsi/), to co-develop research needs with engineering educators from HSIs in the Southwest and Florida through an iterative and emergent analysis process. The major goal of this conference grant was to leverage design thinking methodologies to better understand the Hispanic-serving institutions (HSIs) institutional context and co-develop research needs with educators through an iterative and emergent analysis process.

Towards this end, this project produced the following outcomes:

  • A set of research questions and needs to support the National Science Foundation?s development of an HSI-focused research agenda

  • Educational experiences and prototypes for dissemination within the conference community and more broadly

  • A conference-design framework for identifying non-obvious research needs and engaging educators in the engineering education research and scholarship process

Intellectual Merit This project has advanced the engineering education research community?s understanding of the particular research needs of engineering programs at Hispanic-serving institutions and the students, educators, and staff who make-up those programs. Through workshop activities and follow-up surveys, we developed a set of research questions and needs that have been summarized in a series of conference publications and a public-facing report posted on our conference website (http://eel.utep.edu/hsi/). The findings also expand on the regional and national research needs of HSIs, by reporting on high-level educational challenges facing thirty-six faculty from thirteen HSIs, and highlight key successes that could all serve as the basis for future NSF calls for proposals. The workshops themselves provided a venue for engaging educators from underrepresented HSIs in conversations about the future of engineering education, creating new pathways for interested educators to explore engineering education scholarship and research.

Broader Impact The results of these workshops produced evidence-based insights on the research needs of engineering programs at HSIs. During the workshop, practitioners were able to reflect upon and examine their own educational system, introducing opportunities for developing their own reform efforts or engaging with other participants from their own or a different institution. By seeding the workshops with three innovative approaches to designing educational experiences, practitioners were equipped with approaches they can use to support their students immediately upon returning to their home institution. A subset of ten attendees was also able to participate in the American Society of Engineering Education Annual Conference for the first time and a follow-up workshop where they had the opportunity to build relationships with engineering educators who are also engaged in engineering education reform. Finally, this project has the long-term potential to support the broader engineering education research community?s engagement in research at and in collaboration with HSIs.

References:

Yoder, B. L. (2015). Engineering By the Numbers. ASEE.

Santiago, D., & Soliz, M. (2012). Finding Your Workforce: The Top 25 Institutions Graduating Latinos in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM). Excelencia in Education.
